questions.text: An elderly patient presents with an extremely painful blister characterized by a woody surface. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing fasciitis

 

The elderly patient presents with an extremely painful lower limb blister characterized by a woody surface, which is indicative of necrotizing fasciitis. Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe, rapidly progressing infection of the fascial planes that leads to tissue necrosis. It commonly affects the elderly or those with compromised immune systems and can follow trivial trauma. The infection begins in the fascia and subcutaneous tissue and can quickly spread, leading to gangrene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gas gangrene: This is incorrect as gas gangrene typically presents with a history of trauma or puncture wounds, and the presence of crepitus (air pockets) in the tissue, which is not described here.

 

Option B. Cellulitis: This is incorrect as cellulitis is an inflammation of the subcutaneous fat, usually without the formation of blisters or a woody texture, and it is not typically as painful as described.

 

Option D. DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): This is incorrect as DVT presents with limb swelling and pain but does not cause blistering or a woody surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe infection that affects the fascia and subcutaneous tissues, leading to extreme pain, blistering, and a woody surface, and requires prompt medical attention.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriche’s syndrome.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

questions.text: A patient has undergone surgery as shown in the image below.  After this surgery, the patient presents with pallor, dizziness and sweating whenever he has a large meal. What could this be? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dumping syndrome

 

In a patient following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, who develop pallor, dizziness and sweating after a large meal, dumping syndrome is most likely.

 

Dumping syndrome is complication following gastric reconstructions and vagotomy

 

Dumping syndrome is of two types

 

  • Early dumping syndrome 
    1. Occurs due to rapid influx of fluid due to hyperosmolar contents in bowel
    2. Starts within 10 mins of meals intake
    3. Clinical features: epigastric fullness, bloating, nausea & vomiting, symptoms of hypotension: light-headedness, fainting
  • Late dumping syndrome
    1. Sweating, tachycardia, dizziness after 45 mins to 1 hour of eating food
    2. Worsens with exercise
    3. It is due to rebound hypoglycemia seen due to excessive Insulin release

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reflux gastritis presents with heartburn, regurgitation, chest pain.

 

Option C. Post-vagotomy diarrhea presents with loose watery stools, increased frequency of bowel movements and abdominal cramps.

 

Option D. Frey’s syndrome presents with gustatory sweating. It is seen after parotid surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dumping syndrome, a common complication following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, presents with pallor, dizziness, and sweating after a large meal due to rapid influx of fluid and hyperosmolar contents in the bowel.

choices.text: Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery
It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nephroblastoma?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

 

Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It can spread through both hematogenous routes and lymphatics, and treatment typically involves a combination of surgery and chemotherapy. However, while it is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, it is not the most common. That distinction belongs to neuroblastoma.

 

It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children: This statement is incorrect. While Wilms tumor is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in pediatric patients is neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spread by lymphatics: Nephroblastoma can spread via lymphatics, usually involving regional lymph nodes first. Although hematogenous spread is more common, lymphatic spread does occur.

 

Option B. Early lung metastasis: Wilms tumor often metastasizes to the lungs early in its course. Children diagnosed with Wilms tumor typically undergo chest imaging to check for lung metastasis.

 

Option C. Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery: The standard treatment for Wilms tumor involves surgical removal of the tumor followed by chemotherapy to eliminate any remaining cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroblastoma is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, not Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

questions.text: What is the best investigation for GERD? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring

 

GERD has triad of retrosternal heart burn, epigastric pain and regurgitation. Investigation of choice for GERD: 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy: While it can visualize the damage or inflammation caused by GERD (like esophagitis or Barrett's esophagus), it doesn't provide direct evidence of acid reflux. It's useful for assessing complications or when GERD symptoms are severe.

 

Option C. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): Beneficial in evaluating hiatus hernias.

 

Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): It doesn't directly measure acid reflux or its effects on the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for diagnosing GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) is 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of a child undergoing inguinal hernia repair is shown, with a marked vein in the spermatic cord. What is the likely structure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular vein

 

During an open inguinal hernia repair, especially in the context of congenital hernias, the structures encountered within the spermatic cord are crucial for identification and preservation. The testicular vein is one of the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord, alongside the testicular artery and vas deferens. This vein is responsible for draining blood from the testes and is often seen during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

In the provided intraoperative image, the marked structure is consistent with the testicular vein due to its anatomical position and its association with the spermatic cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: The femoral vein lies posterior to the inguinal canal and is not encountered during an open inguinal hernia repair. It is located within the femoral triangle and is not related to the spermatic cord.

 

Option B. Obturator vein: The obturator vein is also located posterior to the inguinal canal, passing through the obturator foramen. It is not visible or involved in inguinal hernia repairs as it lies deep in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Inferior epigastric vein: The inferior epigastric vein is positioned anterior to the peritoneum and supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It does not travel within the spermatic cord and would not be seen during an open hernia repair involving the spermatic cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an open inguinal hernia repair, the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord are the testicular veins. Other veins such as the femoral, obturator, and inferior epigastric veins are located posterior to the inguinal canal and are not seen within the spermatic cord during such procedures.

questions.text: A patient with a history of hematochezia undergoes a procedure using the device shown in the image. Identify the device. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pile banding kit

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Barron's band ligator:

 

  • Used for rubber band ligation of internal hemorrhoids
  • Has bands loaded that are deployed around hemorrhoid base
  • Causes strangulation of hemorrhoid tissue
  • Most commonly used for grade II hemorrhoids
  • Done as outpatient procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stapler for hemorrhoids: Incorrect as a stapler is a circular device used for stapled hemorrhoidopexy (PPH procedure)

 

Option C. Hemorrhoidectomy kit: Incorrect as this would include surgical instruments for excision

 

Option D. Fistula surgery kit: Incorrect as this would include instruments for fistula surgery like probes, curettes and scissors



Educational Objective:

 

A Pile Banding Kit is used in rubber band ligation for treating Grade II and III hemorrhoids. It applies a rubber band at the base of the hemorrhoid, leading to necrosis and sloughing.


Haemorrhoids Grading and Treatment

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a minimally invasive technique that involves the insertion of a needle through the stomach wall under ultrasound guidance to obtain a sample of pancreatic tissue. EUS-guided biopsy has a high diagnostic accuracy and is considered the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma as it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI-guided biopsy: Is a technique that uses magnetic resonance imaging to guide the insertion of a needle to obtain a tissue sample. This technique is not commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its low accuracy.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Is a minimally invasive surgical technique that involves the insertion of a laparoscope through small incisions in the abdomen to visualize the pancreas and obtain a tissue sample. Laparoscopic biopsy is a more invasive option than EUS-guided biopsy but may be used when other methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option D. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Involves the insertion of a needle through the abdominal wall to obtain a tissue sample from the pancreas. This technique is less commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to the risk of complications such as bleeding and infection.

 

Overall, EUS-guided biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

questions.text: The Alvarado score is used for the diagnosis of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Acute Appendicitis

 

Explanation:

 

The Alvarado score (also known as the MANTRELS score) is a clinical scoring system specifically developed to diagnose acute appendicitis. It uses 8 criteria with a total possible score of 10 points. The components of the score include: Migratory RIF pain (1 point), Anorexia (1 point), Nausea/vomiting (1 point), Tenderness in RIF (2 points), Rebound tenderness (1 point), Elevated temperature (1 point), Leukocytosis (2 points), and Shift to left of neutrophils (1 point). A score of 7 or more is strongly predictive of acute appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatitis - Pancreatitis diagnosis relies on clinical features, elevated serum amylase/lipase levels, and imaging. The Ranson criteria or APACHE II scores are used for severity assessment, not the Alvarado score.

 

Option B. Cholecystitis - Diagnosis relies on Murphy's sign, ultrasonography findings, and laboratory values. The Tokyo Guidelines provide diagnostic criteria for acute cholecystitis, not the Alvarado score.

 

Option C. Turner's Syndrome - This is a genetic condition diagnosed by karyotype analysis showing 45, XO. Clinical scoring systems are not used for the diagnosis of genetic conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Alvarado score is a validated clinical decision tool specifically designed for diagnosing acute appendicitis, with a score ≥7 having high diagnostic value, helping to reduce negative appendectomy rates.

questions.text: What is the appropriate BIRADS category for a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BIRADS 2

 

BIRADS 2 is used for benign findings. Given that the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a well-recognized benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most suitable category for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BIRADS 1 or 2: BIRADS 1 is assigned to a category when there is no suspicion of malignancy, and BIRADS 2 is used when there is a benign finding. In this case, since the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most appropriate category.

 

Option B. BIRADS 2 or 4: BIRADS 4 is used when there is a suspicious abnormality that may or may not be cancerous. Since the histology in this case indicates a fibroadenoma appearance, which is benign, BIRADS 4 would not be appropriate.

 

Option C. BIRADS 2, 3, or 4: BIRADS 3 is assigned when there is a probably benign finding that requires short-term follow-up. In this case, since the histology indicates a fibroadenoma appearance (a benign finding), BIRADS 3 and BIRADS 4 would not be applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, the appropriate BIRADS category is BIRADS 2.

 

Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor that poses a low risk of malignancy. The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) categories are used to assess the likelihood of malignancy of breast lesions seen on mammograms, ultrasounds, or MRI. Grades 1 and 2 have a very low probability of being malignant, while grade 3 has a slightly higher probability of malignancy.

 

Grades 4 and 5 are considered suspicious and warrant further investigation as they have a higher probability of malignancy.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulbar urethral injury 

 

  • The image provided is a radiographic image, from a retrograde urethrogram, is of bulbar urethral injury with stricture. 
  • This injury occurs in the bulbar part of the urethra, which is located between the penile urethra and the membranous urethra. This type of injury can result from trauma, typically blunt perineal trauma, and can be identified on imaging by contrast extravasation or interruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Membranous urethral injury: This type of injury occurs in the membranous portion of the urethra, which is the shortest, least dilatable, and most fixed part of the urethra. It's often associated with pelvic fractures and can be identified by an abnormal urethrogram.

 

Option C. Penile stricture: A penile stricture is a narrowing of the penile urethra. It would be visualized on a urethrogram as a narrowed segment but would not show the contrast extravasation typically seen in traumatic injuries.

 

Option D. Prostate hyperplasia: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is an enlargement of the prostate gland and can cause obstruction of the urethral passage. On imaging, BPH would not present as a urethral injury but could show an enlarged prostate and possibly a post-void residual.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A bulbar urethral injury through radiographic imaging shows contrast extravasation or interruption in the bulbar urethra, indicative of trauma to this specific area.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is done for the treatment of Pilonidal sinus as shown? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transposition flap

 

The image provided shows a surgical procedure used to treat a pilonidal sinus. The procedure depicted is a Limberg flap, also known as a rhomboid flap. In this technique, a rhomboid-shaped piece of tissue adjacent to the excision site is cut and transposed to cover the wound created after the excision of the pilonidal sinus. This movement of tissue from the side to the gap is characteristic of a transposition flap. The Limberg flap is effective for ensuring tension-free closure and reducing the recurrence of the pilonidal sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial flap: This type of flap involves tissue that has a specific blood supply along its axis, which is not depicted in the image provided.

 

Option B. Rotation flap: A rotation flap involves rotating tissue around a pivot point to cover a defect. The image shows transposition rather than rotation.

 

Option C. Advancement flap: This involves moving tissue forward to cover a defect, typically in a straight line, which is not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Limberg flap, used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus, is a type of transposition flap where tissue from the adjacent side is cut, rotated, and used to close the defect created by the excision of the pilonidal sinus.

choices.text: Posterior urethral valves
Ectopic ureter / Duplicate ureter
Urinary tract infection

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is having continuous dribbling of urine with normal voiding pattern. What is the most likely cause? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ectopic ureter/ Duplicate ureter

 

An ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly where the ureter does not insert into the bladder in its normal anatomical location. In females, it can drain urine into the urethra, vagina, or other locations outside the bladder, leading to continuous dribbling of urine because the urine bypasses the normal control mechanisms of the bladder. This is the most likely cause in the presented case of a 7-year-old girl with continuous dribbling of urine and a normal voiding pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Posterior urethral valves:
    • This is a congenital condition mostly seen in male infants and involves an obstruction in the posterior urethra. It is characterized by a weak urine stream, difficulty in emptying the bladder, recurrent urinary tract infections, and potential kidney damage. It is not common in females and therefore is not the most likely cause in this scenario.
  • Option C. Urinary tract infection (UTI):
    • A UTI can cause symptoms such as urgency, frequency, pain during urination, and sometimes incontinence. However, continuous dribbling of urine is not typical of a UTI, and such infections are usually accompanied by symptoms like pain, burning sensation, and fever, which are not mentioned in this case.
  • Option D. Vesicoureteric reflux:
    • This condition involves the backward flow of urine from the bladder to the ureters and possibly the kidneys. It can lead to recurrent UTIs and potential kidney damage, but it does not typically present as continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young female patient presenting with continuous dribbling of urine with a normal voiding pattern, consider the possibility of an ectopic ureter or duplicated ureter. This congenital anomaly allows urine to bypass the bladder, leading to continuous leakage.

questions.text: An adult male presented to the OPD with a swelling in the scrotum which was painful. The patient was having fever as well. The swelling was in relation to the tunica vaginalis and fluid collection was present. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocele

 

The patient presents with a painful scrotal swelling accompanied by fever. The swelling is noted to be in relation to the tunica vaginalis with fluid collection, which points towards a secondary hydrocele due to an underlying condition.

 

The combination of painful scrotal swelling and fever is indicative of an inflammatory or infectious process, most commonly acute epididymo-orchitis. This condition is inflammation of the epididymis and testicle, often caused by bacterial infection. The presence of fluid around the testicle, known as a hydrocele, is a secondary response to the inflammation.

 

A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum. Secondary hydroceles can develop in response to infections, injuries, or inflammatory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicocele: This is an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum (the pampiniform plexus). It is typically not associated with fever or acute pain and does not involve fluid collection related to the tunica vaginalis.

 

Option C. Cystocele: This condition involves the bladder bulging into the vaginal space and is unrelated to scrotal swelling.

 

Option D. Torsion testis: Testicular torsion involves the twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to severe pain and swelling. While torsion can occur in adults, it is more common in adolescents. It usually does not present with fever unless secondary infection occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful scrotal swelling with fever and fluid collection in an adult male, particularly in relation to the tunica vaginalis, suggests a diagnosis of secondary hydrocele due to epididymo-orchitis.

questions.text: A homosexual man presented with painful defecation, foul-smelling protruding mass through anus which is non-reducible. Biopsy of the mass shows squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What will be the next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoradiation

 

For a patient diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, the first line of management is chemoradiation (called the Nigro regimen). This approach provides good tumor control, preserves the anal sphincter function, and avoids a permanent colostomy. If chemoradiation fails or if there's a recurrence, surgical interventions like APR might be considered.

 

  • This is a combination treatment modality that uses both chemotherapy and radiation therapy to treat cancer. Chemoradiation is the primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. It provides both local control of the tumor and treats potential microscopic disease. The Nigro regimen, combining 5-FU with mitomycin C or cisplatin and external beam radiation, has shown excellent results in treating this cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colostomy: Colostomy might be used as a temporary or permanent measure in cases where the anus or rectum is obstructed or needs to be bypassed. It's not the primary treatment for anal squamous cell carcinoma but may be used in certain situations to manage symptoms or complications.

 

Option C. Excision: While excision could be considered for some tumors, for anal squamous cell carcinoma, simple excision might not offer the best oncological outcomes compared to chemoradiation. Excision alone without addressing potential microscopic disease can lead to recurrence.

 

Option D. Abdominoperineal Resection (APR): This is a surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, and sigmoid colon are removed. It results in a permanent colostomy. Abdominoperineal resection was historically the treatment for anal cancer. However, with the success of chemoradiation in treating squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, APR is now reserved for those who don't respond to chemoradiation or have recurrent disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is chemoradiation, which preserves anal sphincter function and avoids the need for a permanent colostomy.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Uro bags - collection of urine.
  • An underwater seal bag- collection of drainage fluid from the thoracic cavity.
  • Nasogastric tube / Ryle's tube - Used for Nasogastric feeding / Stomach wash / Aspiration
