choices.text: Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

questions.text: A patient who had kidney stones removed presents with flank pain 4-5 years postoperatively and a foreign body is observed on imaging. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

 

The patient presents with flank pain years after having kidney stones removed, and imaging reveals a foreign body, likely a retained double J ureteric stent. Double J stents are often placed during procedures to manage kidney or ureteric stones to ensure urine drainage but should be removed once they are no longer needed.

 

The appropriate management in this case is to perform an endoscopy to remove the retained stent. Retaining a stent for too long can cause complications such as stone formation on the stent, obstruction, or infection, which explains the patient's current symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy and Cystoscopic removal: Not required in this situation

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is incorrect as it is used to assess the urethra, not the ureter or kidneys. It is used for diagnosing urethral strictures or ruptures.

 

Option D. Leave the foreign body inside: This is incorrect and not a viable option as the foreign body (stent) is causing symptoms and potential complications, and must be removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopy is the appropriate procedure for the removal of a retained ureteric stent, which can cause complications if left inside the body for too long.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute Pancreatitis

 

  • A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, which can be caused by gallstones, alcohol consumption, and other factors. It can lead to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and increased heart rate. A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. Other signs include sentinel loop, renal halo and colon cut-off.
  • Other causes of gasless abdomen on Xray include:
    • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults
    • Bowel ischemia
    • Intestinal atresia
    • Ascites
    • Gastroenteritis
    • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative Colitis: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum. Symptoms include diarrhea, often with blood or pus, abdominal pain, and rectal pain. In children, it may affect growth. A gasless abdomen on X-ray is not a typical feature of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine "telescopes" into another, leading to bowel obstruction. This can cut off the blood supply to the affected portion of the intestine. It is one of the most common abdominal emergencies affecting children under two. Classic symptoms include intermittent abdominal pain, "currant jelly" stools, and a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the abdomen. While it can lead to changes in an abdominal X-ray like dilated small bowel loops, a gasless abdomen is not the primary diagnostic feature of intussusception.

 

Option D. Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from mouth to anus. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. Inflammation caused by Crohn's disease can involve different areas of the digestive tract in different people. Unlike acute pancreatitis, a gasless abdomen is not a primary feature seen with Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gasless abdomen on X-ray is commonly associated with acute pancreatitis in children presenting with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. This condition should be considered when evaluating similar clinical presentations.

questions.text: A patient presents incidentally with the following findings as shown below. He does not report any discomfort. According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C2A

 

  • Given the scenario showing asymptomatic varicose veins, it corresponds to C2a in the CEAP classification system.
  • C2A: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are asymptomatic (suffix A).
  • The CEAP classification system is used to categorize varicose veins based on their clinical characteristics.
  • The acronym stands for Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomic, and Pathophysiologic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2S: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are symptomatic (suffix S), meaning the patient would experience symptoms like pain, aching, swelling, or other discomforts. Since the patient reports no discomfort, this is not the correct classification.

 

Option C. C4a: This stage represents more advanced skin changes, such as pigmentation or eczema, due to chronic venous disease. The patient only has varicose veins without skin changes, so this classification is incorrect.

 

Option D. C1: Represents telangiectasia or reticular veins, which are smaller than varicose veins. The image and clinical description indicate larger varicose veins, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease.
  •  For asymptomatic varicose veins, the appropriate classification is C2a, distinguishing them from symptomatic cases and those with more advanced skin changes.

questions.text: All of the following criteria are used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. ROME Criteria

 

Explanation:

 

ROME Criteria is not used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis. The validated scoring systems for severity assessment in acute pancreatitis include Ranson, Glasgow (Imrie's), APACHE, SAPS, SOFA, MODS, and modified Marshall scoring systems. Additional tools include the BISAP Score and CT Severity Index. ROME Criteria is used for functional gastrointestinal disorders, not for assessing pancreatitis severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranson Criteria - This is a valid severity assessment tool for acute pancreatitis. It uses 11 parameters (5 at admission and 6 at 48 hours), with a score ≥3 indicating severe pancreatitis. Parameters include age, white blood cell count, blood glucose, LDH, AST at admission and hematocrit fall, BUN rise, arterial oxygen, calcium levels, base deficit, and fluid sequestration at 48 hours.

 

Option B. APACHE-II - This is a valid severity assessment tool used in intensive care settings for pancreatitis patients. It assesses physiological parameters and can be calculated at any time during hospitalization, making it more dynamic than Ranson criteria.

 

Option C. Imrie's Criteria - Also known as the Glasgow scoring system, this is a valid severity assessment tool similar to Ranson but with fewer parameters. It also uses a cutoff of ≥3 to indicate severe pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Severity stratification in acute pancreatitis should be performed using validated scoring systems (Ranson, Glasgow/Imrie, APACHE, BISAP, CT Severity Index) to identify patients at risk for persistent organ failure and complications.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

 

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae is primarily through the prostatic venous plexus or Bateson plexus. Tumor cells spread to the spine and proximal long bones via Bateson's venous plexus, which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.
  • The prostatic venous plexus (or Bateson plexus) is a network of veins surrounding the prostate.
  • The prostatic venous plexus has connections to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because of this unique venous anatomy, tumor cells from the prostate can enter the venous system and bypass the usual portal and caval routes, spreading directly to the spine, specifically the lumbar vertebrae.
  • This is the most common route for metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans coelomic spread: Trans coelomic spread refers to the dissemination of malignant cells across body cavities, such as the pleural, peritoneal, or pericardial spaces. This method of spread is most commonly seen with primary cancers of the ovary, stomach, and colon. In the context of prostate cancer, trans coelomic spread is not a typical route to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Option C. Inferior vesical vein: The inferior vesical vein drains the urinary bladder. While there are venous communications between the prostatic plexus and the vesical veins, the direct spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae through the inferior vesical vein alone is less common than through the prostatic venous plexus.

 

Option D. Internal iliac vein: The internal iliac vein drains blood from the pelvis and perineum. While prostate cancer can spread through the internal iliac vein as part of its venous drainage, this route is not the primary pathway to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation
Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

 

The image shows a reducible swelling on the patient's back, which strongly suggests a hernia. Hernias are defined as protrusions of an organ or tissue through an abnormal opening. When a hernia is reducible, it means that the protruded organ or tissue can be pushed back into its original place.

 

The standard treatment for a reducible hernia is surgical repair. This often involves reducing the hernia and reinforcing the weakened area with a mesh to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly important to avoid complications such as strangulation or incarceration of the herniated contents, which can become medical emergencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage: This procedure is typically used for abscesses or other collections of pus, not for hernias. Hernias do not require drainage as there is no infection involved.

 

Option B. Reduce the swelling and do the observation: While reducing the swelling might temporarily alleviate symptoms, observation alone is not a definitive treatment for a hernia. Without surgical repair, the hernia is likely to recur and may lead to complications.

 

Option D. Observation alone: This option is not advisable for hernias as it does not address the underlying defect in the abdominal wall or the risk of potential complications. Hernias generally require surgical intervention to prevent recurrence and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth, which appears bluish-red and transilluminates positively. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ranula

 

A ranula is a type of mucous cyst that forms in the floor of the mouth. It typically presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling that transilluminates positively due to its fluid content. Ranulas are caused by the obstruction of salivary glands, leading to the accumulation of mucous.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: This is incorrect because dermoid cysts contain sebaceous material and hair, and they do not transilluminate. They are also not typically bluish-red in appearance.

 

Option C. Sublingual growth: This is incorrect as a general term that does not specify a cystic or transilluminating nature.

 

Option D. Sublingual cyst: This is incorrect as it does not have transillumination and bluish-red color.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ranula presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth that transilluminates positively, due to the accumulation of mucous from an obstructed salivary gland.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly seen after bariatric gastric bypass surgery? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is a common bariatric surgery, second to sleeve gastrectomy. The most common deficiency observed after this procedure is iron deficiency anemia. This occurs because the stomach, which plays a role in converting dietary iron to its absorbable form, is partially bypassed. Reduced stomach acid production post-surgery also impairs iron absorption. This is particularly concerning for menstruating women, who are at higher risk for iron deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficiency of vitamin D: After a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, there's a reduced absorptive surface area and altered gut flora, leading to decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin D. However, this deficiency is less common compared to iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option B. Deficiency of calcium: Reduced stomach acid production post-gastric bypass can affect the solubilization of calcium salts, leading to decreased calcium absorption. This deficiency is often associated with vitamin D deficiency but is not as common as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Protein-calorie malnutrition: After bariatric surgery, especially gastric bypass, the reduced stomach size can lead to decreased food intake. If protein intake is not adequate, it can lead to protein-calorie malnutrition, particularly in the early post-operative period. However, this is less common compared to iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common deficiency observed after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two or more of the following criteria are present: hyperthermia or hypothermia, Tachypnea or low PaCO2, Tachycardia, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic blood pressure is not included in the SIRS criteria. Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented infection.

 

This is not a criterion for SIRS. SIRS criteria typically include fever or hypothermia, tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute), tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute), and abnormal white blood cell count. Low blood pressure is more related to septic shock, which can be a consequence of severe sepsis but is not one of the primary criteria for SIRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius: This is a criterion for SIRS.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 bpm: This is a criterion for SIRS. Elevated respiratory rate (>20 breaths per minute) or paCO2 < 32 mm of Hg is one of the criteria used to diagnose SIRS.

 

Option D. Heart rate >90 min: This is a criterion for SIRS. Tachycardia, defined as a heart rate greater than 90 beats per minute, is one of the key criteria for SIRS.

 

In summary, Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg (option A) is not a criterion for SIRS, while the other options (B, C, and D) are all criteria for SIRS.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical wall repair 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital condition where the baby is born with the intestines located outside of the body through an opening in the abdominal wall. 

 

This is the most appropriate management strategy. It involves surgical correction where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdominal cavity and the abdominal wall defect is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This is not an appropriate strategy for gastroschisis. Without prompt surgical intervention, the exposed intestines are at risk of infection, dehydration, and injury.

 

Option C. Slowly putting it inside: While the concept of gradually reducing the bowel back into the abdominal cavity (sometimes called "silo" reduction) is a valid approach, it is performed as part of the surgical management and under controlled conditions, not as a standalone treatment.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This option is not relevant to the management of gastroschisis. There is no need to excise the bowel unless there is nonviable tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management for a neonate with gastroschisis is immediate surgical repair to return the intestines to the abdominal cavity and close the defect in the abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had been ongoing for the past 24 hours. He reported that he had been consuming alcohol heavily for the past few weeks. The physical examination revealed tenderness in the upper abdomen with no visible signs of jaundice. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan was performed, which revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. The patient was started on appropriate treatment, and blood tests were ordered to help diagnose the condition. Which enzyme is most likely to be elevated in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum lipase

 

  • An alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis is most likely to have elevated serum lipase levels.
  •  Clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzymes in the plasma are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase is a more sensitive and specific marker of acute pancreatitis than amylase, which can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum GGT : GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver. It is an important marker for liver disease, especially conditions associated with bile duct obstruction. Elevated GGT would not specifically indicate pancreatitis.

 

Option B. CEA : CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) is a tumor marker, primarily used to monitor certain types of cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. It can be elevated in some pancreatic cancers as well, but it's not specifically used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Serum bilirubin: Bilirubin is a product of red blood cell breakdown and is processed by the liver. Elevated serum bilirubin levels can indicate liver disease or a blockage of the bile duct, which can be due to a stone, tumor, or other causes. In the context of pancreatitis, elevated bilirubin can be seen in biliary pancreatitis when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct, but it's not a specific marker for pancreatitis itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum lipase is the most specific enzyme for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol consumption.
  •  It rises within 12 to 24 hours of pancreatic injury and remains elevated for 7-14 days, making it a crucial diagnostic marker for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in damage control surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vascular anastomosis

 

Damage control surgery (DCS) is a staged approach that involves minimal intervention to stabilize the patient and perform definitive surgery later. The focus of DCS is on hemorrhage control, resuscitation, and limiting contamination. It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage. After the initial steps of DCS, definitive surgery involving vascular anastomosis may be performed.

 

Vascular anastomosis is not typically included in damage control surgery.

 

Vascular anastomosis, is generally not performed during the initial phase of damage control surgery. Damage control surgery prioritizes addressing life-threatening injuries and stabilizing the patient. Complex procedures like vascular anastomosis are typically deferred to later, definitive surgery, after the patient's condition has been stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhage control: Hemorrhage control is a critical component of damage control surgery. The primary goal of damage control surgery is to address life-threatening bleeding and stop any ongoing hemorrhage. Surgeons often use various techniques, such as packing wounds or applying temporary closures, to achieve hemorrhage control during the initial phase of damage control surgery.

 

Option B. Resuscitation: Resuscitation is a key aspect of damage control surgery. Patients who require damage control surgery are often in a state of shock due to significant blood loss and trauma. Resuscitation involves stabilizing the patient's condition by providing fluids, blood products, and other supportive measures to restore blood volume and vital organ function. It is usually done in ICU after hemorrhage is stopped.

 

Option C. Decontamination: Decontamination may be necessary in specific situations, such as chemical or biological contamination, gross spillage into peritoneum or dirty wounds.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

vascular anastomosis (option D) is not a standard part of damage control surgery, while the other options (A, B, and C) are relevant components of this surgical approach.

questions.text: A man in his 50s comes to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. During the examination, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is measured at 90/50mmg. Guarding is observed during a per abdomen examination. An erect abdominal X-ray is provided. What is the best management in this case based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

 

Given clinical scenario of tachycardia, hypotension with abdominal guarding and X ray showing pneumoperitoneum is suggestive of hollow viscous perforation. The best management would be laparotomy and repair. The next step would be IV fluids.

 

Given the patient's severe abdominal pain, guarding during the physical examination, tachycardia, and hypotension, along with X ray findings suggest a perforation. An exploratory laparotomy would allow for direct visualization and treatment of the underlying cause. In emergent situations like this, a surgical exploration might be the most appropriate next step. Hence, OPTION C is the most appropriate choice among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG abdomen: Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize abdominal organs. It may be used for a preliminary assessment of abdominal pain, but in the case of a patient with severe pain, hemodynamic instability (as indicated by tachycardia and hypotension), and guarding, accompanied by X ray showing free air, a USG would not add to the management.

 

Option B. IV fluids: Administering IV fluids can help stabilize the patient's blood pressure and is an essential immediate measure. However, fluids alone might not address the underlying cause of perforation.

 

Option D. Elective surgery: Elective surgery is a planned procedure that is done when a condition is not immediately life-threatening. Given the severity of the patient's symptoms and the potential for an acute abdominal catastrophe, waiting for an elective procedure is not appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, the space within the abdomen that contains the intestines, liver, and other abdominal organs.

 

Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:

 

Patients with a significant amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity due to organ perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, signs of peritonitis (like guarding and rebound tenderness), and systemic symptoms like fever or shock. An erect abdominal X-ray is a commonly used diagnostic modality to detect pneumoperitoneum. On the X-ray, free air under the diaphragm, or "free subdiaphragmatic air", is a classic finding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type III

 

The classification of achalasia into types I, II, and III is based on the Chicago Classification. This system uses high-resolution manometry to categorize esophageal motility disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

 

The ileocolic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) that supplies blood to the appendix and the cecum. During an appendicectomy procedure, it is crucial to identify and ligate the appendicular branch of ileocolic artery to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. Failure to do so can result in bleeding complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right colic artery: The right colic artery is another branch of the SMA that supplies blood to the ascending colon and the right side of the transverse colon. Ligating the right colic artery is not a standard part of an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option C. Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies blood to the rectum. It is not directly related to an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric artery: The superior mesenteric artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to various parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum and ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.

 

Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with diffuse, severely contaminated perforation peritonitis due to hollow viscus. He underwent laparotomy for it. On day 7 post-op, he developed signs of wound infection and subsequently, the wound showed dehiscence with exposure of underlying tissues as shown below. His vital signs are stable with no evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vacuum assisted closure (VAC)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient underwent laparotomy for perforation peritonitis and developed wound infection followed by wound dehiscence on postoperative day 7. Given that:

 

  • The wound is open with exposed underlying tissues.
  • Vital signs are stable.
  • No evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis.

 

This suggests a "burst abdomen" or post-op wound dehiscence, which is best managed using Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC therapy).

 

  • Promotes granulation tissue formation and wound healing.
  • Reduces bacterial load and infection risk.
  • Decreases edema and maintains a moist environment.
  • Prepares the wound for secondary closure or grafting if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suturing of Wound → Incorrect

 

  • Primary closure is not recommended because the wound is infected and dehiscent.
  • Attempting suturing would increase the risk of abscess formation and wound breakdown.

 

Option C. Normal Saline-Soaked Gauze → Partially Correct but Not Ideal

 

  • Saline dressings can be used but do not actively promote wound healing as well as VAC therapy.
  • More suitable for minor dehiscence, not large wounds with exposed tissue.

 

Option D. None of the Above → Incorrect

 

  • The patient requires wound management to prevent secondary infections and facilitate healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy is the best treatment for wound dehiscence after laparotomy, as it promotes granulation tissue formation, reduces infection risk, and optimizes healing.

choices.text: During palpation, over the left hypochondrium

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a history of projectile vomiting and poor weight gain. Physical examination reveals an abdominal mass in the epigastrium, and the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is suspected. An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. During feeding

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is a condition where the pylorus becomes hypertrophied and thickened. This leads to gastric outlet obstruction and symptoms such as projectile vomiting, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances.

 

True. During feeding, or immediately after, the thickened muscle of the pylorus might be most palpable. As the stomach tries to empty its contents through the narrowed pylorus, the hypertrophied muscle can contract and become more prominent. This is called the "olive-like mass" which is palpable in the epigastrium to the right of the midline. This sign is pathognomonic for CHPS. The act of feeding induces peristaltic waves in the stomach, making the pyloric mass more prominent and easier to palpate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Soon after birth: CHPS typically presents in the third to fifth week of life, although it can be present at birth. It is rare to palpate the mass immediately after birth. The symptoms usually progress, and the hypertrophic pylorus becomes more palpable as the condition worsens.

 

Option C. During palpation, over the left hypochondrium: The pylorus is located on the right side of the abdomen, so palpating the left hypochondrium wouldn't help in detecting a mass related to CHPS.

 

Option D. During palpation, over the epigastrium: While the hypertrophied pyloric muscle can indeed be felt in the epigastrium, its palpability becomes much more distinct during or after feeding due to the reasons mentioned in option A. The epigastrium is the upper central region of the abdomen and is the location where the "olive-like mass" of CHPS is most frequently palpated.

 

Educational Objective:


In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the characteristic "olive-like mass" is most easily palpated during or immediately after feeding when the stomach contracts against the hypertrophied pyloric muscle.

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia


Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a patient with metabolic syndrome predisposes to hyperglycemia. Metabolic syndrome is characterized by insulin resistance, often seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and, in some cases, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Insulin resistance impairs the body’s ability to utilize glucose efficiently. When TPN, which is high in glucose, is administered, the already compromised insulin response leads to elevated blood glucose levels, resulting in hyperglycemia. This is a common complication in patients receiving TPN, especially those with underlying metabolic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reactive Hypoglycemia: Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose levels drop excessively after eating, due to an overproduction of insulin. It is not typically associated with TPN or metabolic syndrome, as TPN administration generally leads to hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: While hyperlipidemia is a component of metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct complication specifically associated with TPN. Although TPN can contain lipids, its primary complication related to metabolic syndrome is hyperglycemia due to glucose intolerance.

 

Option D. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia, characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, can be associated with metabolic syndrome but is not directly induced by TPN administration. The primary metabolic disturbance from TPN in these patients is related to glucose management rather than uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

questions.text: Identify the following image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ranula

 

The given clinical scenario and the image showing a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth points to a diagnosis of a Ranula.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A benign tumor made up of blood vessels, often appearing as a birthmark or red growth.

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: A fluid-filled sac that results from a blockage in the lymphatic system, often present at birth. It presents as a posterior neck swelling.

 

Option C. Branchial cyst: A congenital epithelial cyst that arises from remnants of the branchial arches, usually presenting as a neck lump.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of abdominal pain and fever for the past three days presents to the hospital. The physician orders a chest X-ray in the erect position which shows abnormal findings. Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis will be determined? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • Air under the diaphragm is seen in the given erect radiograph, which is a characteristic finding of hollow viscus perforation.
  •  Perforation of a viscus can lead to peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum due to the spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Clinical features of hollow viscus perforation include abdominal pain, distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, and guarding on palpation.
  •  Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric volvulus: Gastric volvulus refers to the twisting of the stomach on its axis. It can result in obstruction and ischemia. Symptoms include severe epigastric pain, vomiting, and difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube. On imaging, the stomach may be abnormally positioned, often with a characteristic appearance described as an "inverted stomach" or "upside-down stomach." While it can cause serious complications, air under the diaphragm on an erect chest radiograph is not typically associated with gastric volvulus.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is typically caused by bacterial or amoebic infection. Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss. An erect chest radiograph isn't the primary modality to diagnose a liver abscess. Instead, an ultrasound or CT scan of the abdomen would be more appropriate to visualize an abscess within the liver.

 

Option D. Empyema thoracis: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity (space between the lung and the chest wall). It's usually a complication of pneumonia or thoracic surgery. Symptoms include fever, cough, chest pain, and breathlessness. On a chest radiograph, the empyema may appear as a fluid level or a white opacity, depending on its stage and the amount of fluid. An erect chest X-ray may be used to diagnose empyema, but it would not typically show free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Air under the diaphragm seen on an erect chest radiograph is a hallmark finding of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate attention to prevent peritonitis and other severe complications.

choices.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous resolution
Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 2years
Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 5 years of age
Do immediate Surgery

questions.text: Mother while giving a bath to her 9-day old baby noticed that the scrotum of the baby is empty. What treatment should be prescribed to this baby? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wait and watch for spontaneous resolution

 

The clinical scenario given is a case of undescended testis. It gets spontaneously resolved within 3 months. Till then, the best step should be to wait and watch.

 

  • Most undescended testes will descend spontaneously in the first few months of life. This is particularly true for testes that are located high in the scrotum or just outside the external inguinal ring. Therefore, the first approach, especially in infants, is usually to wait and monitor. If the testis hasn't descended by around 3-6 months, further evaluation or treatment might be needed.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 2 years:

 

  • Hormonal therapy, like GnRH, has been used to encourage testicular descent. The results are variable, and the response rate is not very high. If hormonal therapy is unsuccessful, surgical correction (orchidopexy) is typically recommended. Surgery is ideally performed between 6 to 12 months to maximize fertility potential and prevent complications.

 

Option C. Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 5 years of age:

 

  • As stated above, waiting until 5 years for surgery may not be ideal. Delayed treatment can result in reduced fertility and an increased risk of testicular cancer.

 

Option D. Do immediate Surgery:

 

  • Immediate surgical intervention in a 9-day-old baby is not typically recommended. The preferred approach is to monitor for spontaneous resolution first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a newborn with undescended testis, the initial management is to wait and monitor for spontaneous descent within the first few months of life. If the testis has not descended by 3-6 months, further evaluation and potential intervention are considered.

questions.text: A bus conductor presents with dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot. What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP (Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C2

 

Explanation:

 

The CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders categorizes the severity of venous disease based on clinical signs, etiology, anatomy, and pathophysiology. In this system, the "C" (Clinical) classification is particularly useful for describing the visible and palpable signs of venous disease.

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins. This stage is characterized by dilated, tortuous veins that are generally more than 3 mm in diameter, such as the 4 mm veins described in the patient's case.
  • C3: Edema related to venous disease.

 

Given the description of dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm, the patient's condition corresponds to C2 in the CEAP classification, indicating the presence of varicose veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C0: C0 indicates no visible or palpable signs of venous disease, which does not apply to this patient who has visible varicose veins.

 

Option B. C1: C1 indicates the presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins, which are smaller than 3 mm in diameter. This stage does not describe the 4 mm varicose veins observed in this patient.

 

Option D. C3: C3 is used to classify edema related to chronic venous disorders. This does not match the presentation of dilated, tortuous veins without mentioned edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of dilated, tortuous veins larger than 3 mm, such as the 4 mm veins observed in the patient's foot, corresponds to stage C2 in the CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders, indicating varicose veins.

choices.text: Reassure the patient and follow up

questions.text: A lady was incidentally diagnosed with a 0.5 cm solid mass in her Gall Bladder on USG which is immobile and it is diagnosed as a gall bladder polyp. She is asymptomatic. What is the next step in the management? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reassure the patient and follow up

 

The incidental finding of a 0.5 cm asymptomatic gallbladder polyp on ultrasound does not warrant immediate surgical intervention. Polyps smaller than 1 cm are generally benign and do not require surgery unless there are other risk factors such as rapid growth, patient age over 55, or presence of gallstones. Regular follow-up with periodic ultrasound is recommended to monitor the size and characteristics of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy:
    • This is the surgical removal of the gallbladder using a minimally invasive method. It is indicated for polyps larger than 1 cm or if there are other risk factors suggesting a higher likelihood of malignancy. Since the polyp is only 0.5 cm and the patient is asymptomatic, this option is not necessary at this stage.
  • Option C. Open Cholecystectomy:
    • This is a more invasive procedure compared to laparoscopic cholecystectomy. It is typically reserved for cases where laparoscopic surgery is not feasible or if there is suspicion of malignancy. Given the small size of the polyp and the absence of symptoms, this option is not appropriate.
  • Option D. CECT Abdomen:
    • Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen can provide detailed images of abdominal structures. However, for a small, asymptomatic gallbladder polyp, this investigation is not required. It would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation without adding significant value in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an asymptomatic gallbladder polyp smaller than 1 cm, the appropriate management is to reassure the patient and arrange regular follow-up to monitor for any changes in the polyp size or characteristics.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET  PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

 

  • The given postoperative image is suggestive of the "shameful exposure of testes" done after debridement for Fournier’s gangrene.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rare but serious bacterial infection of the scrotum and perineum area leading to gangrene.
  • It is characterized by rapid and progressive necrosis (death) of the tissue in the genital and perineal regions and can spread to the surrounding tissue and organs.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene may include severe pain, swelling, redness, and foul-smelling discharge from the affected area.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) are critical in managing Fournier's gangrene, as the condition can be life-threatening if left untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Torsion of testis: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This cuts off the blood flow and can lead to the death of the testicle if not treated promptly. Symptoms typically include sudden and severe pain in one testicle, swelling, redness, and often nausea and vomiting. The affected testicle may lie horizontally and be high-riding. Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to untwist the spermatic cord and save the testicle.

 

Option B. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is the inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle. It is usually caused by an infection, which can be either bacterial or viral. Symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the scrotal area, often accompanied by fever. The affected area would be tender on palpation. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and pain relief.

 

Option C. Scrotal carcinoma: Scrotal carcinoma would present as a growth or ulcerative lesion on the skin of the scrotum. It wouldn't typically cause the acute, severe symptoms described in the scenario. However, it is essential to consider malignancy in long-standing, non-healing ulcers or growths in the scrotal area.

 

  • Given the severe pain, swelling, redness, and the nature of the postoperative image showing debridement, Fournier's gangrene (Option D) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

choices.text: Stop tobacco and don’t worry about the patch
Chemical cauterization with trichloroacetic acetic acid

questions.text: A chronic tobacco chewer presents with left cheek swelling. On examination a white membrane is seen over the gingiva buccal fold, which doesn’t get rubbed off. What will be your next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical excision and biopsy

 

The patient is likely suffering from leukoplakia in the buccal mucosa. In such cases, a biopsy is crucial to rule out malignancy. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, so direct excision and biopsy are the most appropriate first steps to determine the nature of the lesion and guide further management.

 

Surgical Excision and Biopsy:

 

  • This is the preferred step when dealing with potential premalignant or malignant lesions like leukoplakia. It helps to both treat the lesion (by removing it) and diagnose its exact nature (via the biopsy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop Tobacco and Don’t Worry About the Patch: While quitting tobacco is always beneficial, merely stopping without addressing the lesion can be risky. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, and leaving it untreated without proper diagnosis could lead to missed early cancer detection.

 

Option C. Chemical Cauterization with Trichloroacetic Acid: Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is an agent used for chemical cauterization. It has been used for benign lesions, warts, and certain other conditions, but it’s not the primary method of treatment for suspicious lesions like leukoplakia. Proper histopathological diagnosis is essential before considering treatment options.

 

Option D. MVAC Chemotherapy: MVAC is a chemotherapy regimen that includes Methotrexate, Vinblastine, Doxorubicin (Adriamycin), and Cisplatin. This regimen is typically used for treating advanced bladder cancer. It’s not a frontline treatment for an undiagnosed white patch in the oral cavity like leukoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukoplakia can potentially transform into a malignancy, and thus, any suspicious lesion in the oral cavity should be excised and biopsied for a definitive diagnosis and to rule out cancer.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: Patient presents with urinary complaints with sterile pyuria on urine-analysis. A cystoscopy shows dilated ureteric orifice. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golf hole ureteric orifice

 

The clinical scenario describes a patient with urinary complaints and sterile pyuria, a condition where white blood cells are present in the urine without bacterial infection. The cystoscopy reveals a dilated ureteric orifice, which is characteristic of a golf hole ureteric orifice. This condition can occur due to functional obstruction or vesicoureteral reflux, where the ureteric orifice becomes dilated and appears abnormal on cystoscopy.

 

The key diagnostic clue here is the sterile pyuria combined with the specific appearance of the ureteric orifice on cystoscopy, pointing directly to a golf hole ureteric orifice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bladder diverticuli: Bladder diverticuli are pouches that form on the bladder wall and would appear as sac-like outpouchings rather than a dilated ureteric orifice. They are not typically associated with sterile pyuria.

 

Option C. Bladder ulcer: Bladder ulcers are characterized by mucosal erosions within the bladder and do not present with a dilated ureteric orifice. They may cause hematuria and pain rather than sterile pyuria.

 

Option D. Cystitis: Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, often due to infection. It typically presents with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. In cystitis, cystoscopy would show diffuse bladder wall inflammation rather than a dilated ureteric orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dilated ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy in a patient with sterile pyuria is indicative of a golf hole ureteric orifice, a condition where the orifice is abnormally dilated, often due to reflux or functional obstruction.

questions.text: Identify the image: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Omphalocele

 

The image provided likely shows a neonate with a congenital defect characterized by the intestines and other abdominal organs extending outside of the abdominal cavity but contained within a sac composed of peritoneum and amnion. 

 

This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where the intestines, liver, and occasionally other organs remain outside of the abdomen in a sac because of a failure in the normal return of intestines and other contents back to the abdominal cavity during development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urachal cyst: This is a remnant of the embryonic connection between the bladder and the umbilical cord, which usually closes before birth. A cyst can form if this connection does not close properly. It typically does not involve protrusion of abdominal contents.

 

Option C. Omphalocele with cyst: This option isn't a standard term in medical diagnosis. An omphalocele does not typically have a cyst, but rather a sac that is formed from the peritoneum and amnion, containing the herniated organs.

 

Option D. Umbilical adenoma: This is not a recognized condition related to abdominal wall defects in neonates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Omphalocele is a birth defect characterized by an abdominal wall defect with herniation of abdominal contents into an overlying sac due to a failure of normal return of contents during embryonic development.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with recurrent urinary stone formation except: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyper-citralluria

 

Hypercitraturia (elevated urinary citrate) is actually protective against stone formation, not a cause of recurrent stones. 

 

Citrate is a natural inhibitor of calcium stone formation as it binds to calcium in urine, forming soluble complexes that prevent calcium from precipitating with oxalate or phosphate. Citrate also directly inhibits crystal growth and aggregation. 

 

In fact, hypocitraturia (low citrate levels) is a risk factor for recurrent stones, and citrate supplementation (potassium citrate) is commonly used for stone prevention. 

 

Normal urinary citrate acts as a protective buffer against stone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperoxaluria: Incorrect. Hyperoxaluria causes recurrent calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stones. Excess oxalate combines with calcium to form insoluble crystals that aggregate into stones.

 

Option B. Hyperuricosuria: Incorrect. Hyperuricosuria leads to uric acid stone formation and can also promote calcium oxalate stones by providing a nidus for heterogeneous nucleation through epitaxy.

 

Option C. Hypercalciuria: Incorrect. Hypercalciuria is the most common metabolic abnormality in stone formers, causing recurrent calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones through supersaturation of urine with calcium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypercitraturia is protective against kidney stones as citrate inhibits calcium stone formation; hypocitraturia (not hypercitraturia) is a risk factor for recurrent urolithiasis.
